verb.description: (of a fabric, rope, or cord) unravel or become worn at the edge, typically through constant rubbing.
examples: the frayed collar of her old coat

noun.description: A situation of intense activity, typically one incorporating an element of aggression or competition.
examples: nineteen companies intend to bid for the contract, with three more expected to enter the fray

origin: Late Middle English: from archaic fray to quarrel, from affray startle, from Anglo-Norman French afrayer (see affray).
